Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A social media post about your cause is currently going viral, and now is the perfect moment to add a comment with more information.
Story: I was just about to type a thoughtful comment on a viral post about climate action—my cause—when my phone buzzed. It was Sam, an old classmate I hadn’t seen in months. “Hey, could you help me move some boxes this afternoon? I’m really stuck.” I glanced at the post again; thousands of people were reading it, and I knew that if I added a clear, informative comment now, it could make a real difference. But Sam sounded desperate, and I remembered how we’d always promised to help each other out. I felt torn—on one hand, I wanted to be the reliable friend who shows up when needed, but on the other, I felt the weight of responsibility to my cause and the rare opportunity to reach so many people. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, my mind racing between loyalty to a person and commitment to a movement, feeling the pressure of both expectations squeezing me from either side.
